title: Solid Perfume Making - Comprehensive Guide from Soapmaking Forum
author: Soapmaking Forum Community
overview: Community-sourced guide to making solid perfumes with various wax and oil ratios, climate considerations, and professional tips

standard_ratios.medium: 3:1 liquid oil to beeswax - good all-around choice

professional_perfumist_recipe.formula: 1/3 beeswax, 1/3 liquid oil (prefer SAO), 1/3 fragrance or EO
professional_perfumist_recipe.note: Higher fragrance ratio than typical - remember solid perfumes only used on small areas

mandy_aftel_recipe.formula: 5ml jojoba oil + 1/2 heaping tsp beeswax + ~20 drops scent
mandy_aftel_recipe.tip: Test by dropping melted mix on plate, rub after 1 minute to check firmness

beeswax.pros: Traditional, easy to find, good hold

cera_bellina.bonus: Reduces or eliminates graininess in shea butter

candelilla.pros: Less sticky than beeswax, vegan friendly
candelilla.ratio: Same ratios as beeswax work fine

carnauba.note: Harder wax, good for humid climates

oil_options.fractionated_coconut: Excellent for wood butter, fast absorbing

climate_considerations.indoor_storage: Homes are fairly temperate - 3:1 good default
climate_considerations.purse_carry: More vulnerable to temperature - go firmer

lauryl_laurate.description: Solid, fast-melting ester with dry powdery feel
lauryl_laurate.usage: Tiny amounts or formula becomes runny

cetyl_alcohol.use: In place of some wax for similar degreasing effect

shea_butter.ratio_example: 10% wax, 50% shea, 40% liquid oil stays solid
shea_butter.graininess: May get grainy with temperature changes - grains melt on contact
shea_butter.tip: Add ROE (rosemary oleoresin extract) to prevent rancidity

fragrance_considerations.discoloration: Strongly discoloring FOs tend to discolor solid perfumes too
fragrance_considerations.ifra_guidelines: Following IFRA makes solid perfumes less concentrated than Eau de Parfum
fragrance_considerations.longevity: 2 hours maximum for most blends - similar to light cologne
fragrance_considerations.base_notes: Not always the longest lasting - results vary

lip_balm_crossover_recipe.result: Stays solid even in yoga pants pocket all day

wood_butter_recipe.uses: Wooden utensils, bowls, dog paws in winter

steamer_trunk_recipe.note: Bergamot and nutmeg go into red zone quickly on EOCalc
steamer_trunk_recipe.modification: Use candelilla instead of beeswax for less stickiness

process_tips.melting: Melt wax in water bath, add oil, add scent last to prevent evaporation
process_tips.testing: Drop on plate, check firmness after 1 minute
process_tips.containers: Small tins, lip balm pots work well
process_tips.shelf_life: With ROE, balms can last 2+ years without rancidity

quiz_questions.q: What is the recommended all-around ratio for solid perfume?
quiz_questions.a: 3:1 liquid oil to beeswax by weight - works for most climates and storage situations
quiz_questions.explanation: 4:1 is too soft for warm areas, 2:1 doesn't have much glide

quiz_questions.q: What is cera bellina and why use it?
quiz_questions.a: Polyglycerol-3 beeswax that provides more glide/slip and reduces shea butter graininess
quiz_questions.explanation: Good substitute when you want smoother application

quiz_questions.q: What is Lauryl Laurate used for?
quiz_questions.a: De-greases formulations while providing slip - use tiny amounts or formula gets runny
quiz_questions.explanation: Creates dry, powdery feel on skin

quiz_questions.q: Why might solid perfumes not last as long as commercial perfumes?
quiz_questions.a: Following IFRA guidelines makes them less concentrated - similar to light cologne (2 hours)
quiz_questions.explanation: Commercial perfumes may use higher fragrance concentrations

achievement_unlocks: Perfume Chemist: Know the wax and oil ratios
Climate Adjuster: Formulate for different temperatures
Professional Formulator: Use advanced ingredients like Lauryl Laurate
